item.title: Photo Essay: Odin Brewery (Seattle, Wa) Pt. I
item.dc:creator: cameronkarsten
item.description: A brewer is a chef. It takes knowledge of your ingredients and skills with your equipment to create a fabulous feast. Same goes for beer brewing. You must know your tools, your ingredients, and the science behind their reactions and interactions. Nick Heppenstall, head brewer of Odin Brewery in Seattle, Washington has perfected this science into a tasty art-form of craftsman beers. With a background in biochemistry, Nick heads up the recipes for all beers coming out of Odin Brewery. His mission is to brew a beer that pairs perfectly with the right kinds of food, and to do this, the beer must have the right density levels of water to sugars, a balanced pH level of acids, and a comfortable temperature with the right carbonation. "Consistency is my first priority. I believe in keeping things simple. If I can do something simple and good, it's easier for me to make it better."
item.content:encoded:
A brewer is a chef. It takes knowledge of your ingredients and skills with your equipment to create a fabulous feast. Same goes for beer brewing. You must know your tools, your ingredients, and the science behind their reactions and interactions. Nick Heppenstall, head brewer of Odin Brewery in Seattle, Washington has perfected this science into a tasty art-form of craftsman beers.

With a background in biochemistry, Nick heads up the recipes for all beers coming out of Odin Brewery. His mission is to brew a beer that pairs perfectly with the right kinds of food, and to do this, the beer must have the right density levels of water to sugars, a balanced pH level of acids, and a comfortable temperature with the right carbonation.

“Consistency is my first priority. I believe in keeping things simple. If I can do something simple and good, it’s easier for me to make it better.”

Water, grains and the essential hop flowers are key ingredients to crafting a fine brew; three ingredients combined into a myriad of concoctions to intensify certain aspects of flavor.  Next add nutmeg, orange peel, extra sugar, or a compound called amylase to discover sweet palettes, higher alcohol percentage or a drier taste.

“My experience in microbiology has been absolutely valuable to my understanding of brewing beer. Anyone who want’s to brew good beer should study microbiology.”

“Beer Fest is a great movie, but I prefer Strange Brew!”

item.title: Three Bike Treks and a Stack of Belgium Waffles (or screaming legs and killer views)
item.dc:creator: cretanchronicles
item.description: March 12, 2012 email:  “OK road warriors, I have 6 people who have confirmed riding up to Omalos this Saturday.  Jenn, Gio, Jimmy, Mel, Cameron, Andy and myself.  Lets plan on 10:00 at Alikianos, 8:30 for waffles at my house, if you are interested.  As you are painfully aware, this winter has been horrible, however, [...]
item.content:encoded:
March 12, 2012 email:  “OK road warriors, I have 6 people who have confirmed riding up to Omalos this Saturday.  Jenn, Gio, Jimmy, Mel, Cameron, Andy and myself.  Lets plan on 10:00 at Alikianos, 8:30 for waffles at my house, if you are interested.  As you are painfully aware, this winter has been horrible, however, this Saturday looks to be full sun, high in the 50′s (10 degrees C) when we start.  Let me know if your status changes.  See you on Saturday!  Rider of the Cretan Mountains,  Richard”  

Richard commutes to work everyday, rain or shine, so his legs were ready for “The Ride”. However, some of us needed some warm-up runs before the big one.  So, last month a few of us set off to test our bike legs on a couple of weekend excursions around the Akrotiri neighborhood – Signal Mountain and Gouverneto.

SIGNAL MOUNTAIN

Signal Mtn. sunrise

This conical-shaped hill on the Akrotiri goes by many names.  Some call it Misty Mountain because of the clouds that obscure its summit in the winter months.  Some call it Signal Mountain because of the antennae that crown its top.  Others call it simply, “the hill outside the base” because the airfield sits in its shadow.  By any name, it provides a good road ascent and killer views.

Signal Mtn. ascent with Mt. Psiloritis over the sea in distance

Descent is sweet

The "we made it!" photo - Signal Mtn.

GOUVERNETO

View south from monastery road

The Akrotiri peninsula is the site of two of the most beautiful monasteries on the island – Agia Triada and its reclusive cousin, Agia Gouverneto.  If you haven’t hiked or biked the monastery road that connects the two, you are missing out on one of the best experiences this island has to offer.  The road narrows and ascends up into a gorge filled with bleating goats perched on the cliffs above and humming beehives tucked into a few small valleys.  But the WOW factor happens as you crest the end of the road where Agia Gouverneto is located.  The view from the summit opens up to reveal a blue panorama of Aegean water as far as the eye can see to the north.

Summit (Agia Gouverneto)

The gang at summit of monastery road

Agia Triada church

OMALOS – The Big One

Pre-ride waffle feast

What better way to carbo-load before an epic ride than to tank up on a break-feast of Richard’s Belgium waffles smothered with peanut butter and pure maple syrup, steaming sausages, fresh-squeezed OJ and rich espresso.  Ready to ride!

Starting point

Saturday morning, March 17th, a sunny but cool St. Patrick’s Day.  The “luck of the Irish” (and the good Lord) were with these the riders –  five guys and a lady ( SOMEONE had to keep all that testosterone in check.)  We were a rag-tag bunch of roadies composed of a British newbie, a couple of Greek iron-men, two 50+ American youngsters, and an Italian stud on a knobby-tired mountain bike.

Mel and Richard

Rather than take the typical route to Omalos like we did on our last ride in November, we took the road less traveled and headed west towards Sougia – a longer yet more scenic path.  Almost immediately, the two iron-men sprinted ahead leaving the rest of us to pace ourselves and enjoy the companionship of the ride.

Gio and Cam

We experienced the expected (a flat tire) and the unexpected (an attack of a couple of killer bees), but nothing could compare with the new rush of adrenaline we experienced when we crested the ridge where the windmills stood.  The view over our left shoulder was north over the Aegean and over our right shoulder was south over the Libyan Sea.   A-MAAA-ZING!   But the ride wasn’t over and, as any biker can testify, the last 12 km was the hardest.  As we headed behind the wind turbines and up the scenic gorge, our legs start screaming for the finish at Omalos plateau.

Windmills on Sougia road

After roughly 30 miles and 4 hours of hill climbing from just above sea level to 4500 feet elevation, we were at the finish point – where the beautiful, snow-covered sleepy and expansive Omalos plateau stretched out before us.

Finish line above Omalos plateau- We ALL made it!

item.title: 2012 Movies Based on Novels I Have Read
item.dc:creator: fandangogroovers
item.category: The Twilight Saga Breaking Dawn Part 2
item.description: I read the book A Princess of Mars by Edgar Rice Burroughs many years ago when I was at school although I enjoyed it at the time hadn’t given it a second thought until the trailers for the movie John Carter appeared a few months ago. Judging from the trailer it is a lose adaptation [...]
item.content:encoded:
I read the book A Princess of Mars by Edgar Rice Burroughs many years ago when I was at school although I enjoyed it at the time hadn’t given it a second thought until the trailers for the movie John Carter appeared a few months ago. Judging from the trailer it is a lose adaptation at best taking characters and ideas but not the plot from the novel originally published nearly a century ago (1917). Given the number of versions Edgar Rice Burroughs other creation, Tarzan it surprising to learn this is the first big screen outing for John Carter and “Barsoom” series of novels. Tomorrows releases got me thinking about other books I have read that will be hitting the cinema this year:

The Hunger Games by Suzanne Collins: From a novel I read a long time ago to one I have only just read. I saw the box set of the three Hunger Games novels while Christmas shopping last year, having seen the movie trailer I purchased the books and read them over Christmas. Although it loses its way in the third book and isn’t as good as Koushun Takami’s Battle Royale with which it will be forever compared (despite Suzanne Collins insistence that she was unaware of the Japanese novel) it is still worth reading. The casting looks to be perfect most notably Jennifer Lawrence as Katniss Everdeen, a character with clear parallels with Ree Dolly, her Oscar nominated role in Winter’s Bone. Release date: 23rd March.

On the Road by Jack Kerouac: The adaptation of this seminal novel of the Beat Generation is a bittersweet one for me, I have often thought it could make an excellent movie but my anticipation is tempered by fear that it will never live up to the book. It is in short, one of my all time favourite novels. Fortunately producer Francis Ford Coppola (who has owned the rights for many years) has chosen a perfect director in the shape of Walter Salles who did a fantastic job with The Motorcycle Diaries (2004) and has assembled a talented young cast. Release date: 21st September. 

The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn – Part 2: The startling revelation, I have read the Twilight books. As for the movies, the first and third actually aren’t bad. Depending on your point of view, spitting Breaking Dawn into two movies is the only way to do justice to the epic final novel or a cynical attempt to extort the maximum amount of cash from the franchises loyal following. I’m going for the latter. Still as with the final part of Harry potter, Part two promises to better than the dull part one. Release date: 16th November

The Great Gatsby by F. Scott Fitzgerald: With four adaptations to date do we need another? The 1974 version staring Robert Redford and Mia Farrow is a good film but is somehow lacking, it fails to capture the mood and the magic of the novel that is as important to “The Lost Generation” as On the Road is to the “Beat Generation“. I was a little dubious of the casting of Leonardo DiCaprio, Carey Mulligan and Tobey Maguire but actually think it could work. It is a novel that deserves a great adaptation, Baz Luhrmann could be the visionary director to give it to us, but why does he have to make it in 3D? UK release TBA, USA: 25th December

item.title: Lucera: A Love Letter
item.dc:creator: gina
item.description: I’ve been back in Australia for almost six weeks now and, true to form for anyone who’s ever gone on holiday to a wonderful place, not a day has gone by where I haven’t thought of Italy. Not a day has gone by where I haven’t thought of Turin in particular, and the punnet of [...]
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been back in Australia for almost six weeks now and, true to form for anyone who’s ever gone on holiday to a wonderful place, not a day has gone by where I haven’t thought of Italy. Not a day has gone by where I haven’t thought of Turin in particular, and the punnet of delicious strawberries my sister and I demolished in two minutes flat at the markets at Porta Palazzo, or walking along the Po on a sunny day, or window shopping along Via Roma. More than anything though, I miss Lucera.

There’s something about that small, run-down, dirty town that makes being back in Sydney almost unbearable. I miss being able to walk from one end of town to the other in an hour, always finding something interesting along the way. I miss the town square, with its cathedral looking utterly majestic in the sun, rain, and snow. I miss the gelato (oh boy, do I miss the gelato). I miss going in to my favourite bar each morning for a cappuccino and brioche and a read of La Gazzetta dello Sport. I miss having a bar using Illy coffee everywhere I turned. I miss the old men selling fresh fruit and vegetables on tiny tables on the sides of small streets. I miss concentrating hard on every step I took to avoid tripping on the cobblestones, and the way my feet hurt after a day of walking on them. I miss the  conversations I overheard on the street, the dialect speaking of a love for and belonging to the town that I could only dream of.

The funniest part of it all is that when I first glimpsed the town from my uncle’s car arriving from Bari, I was scared. It looked nothing like the town I remembered from my four month stay there in 2000. It looked old, run down, small, and dirty, full of stray dogs and rubbish bins overflowing onto the road. It looked sad and it looked scary and I didn’t know how I was going to endure three months there.

I almost wish my thoughts on Lucera hadn’t changed during my stay, so it would be easier for me to accept that it’s going to be two long years before I get to go back, but you know what they say – it’s better to have loved and lost than to have never loved at all.

Here are photos charting my relationship with the town.

Dark, down-trodden, sad.

The antique market held in the town square on the first Sunday of each month.

There are no parks in Lucera (much to my sister’s chagrin), but the town does have a magnificent villa.

These small shrines are everywhere throughout the town.

San Francesco being carried out on the 29th of November, his feast day.

My favourite cafe – in the town square.

item.title: Alberto Seveso’s stunning a Due Colori series
item.dc:creator: SL
item.description: Master Italian photographer/graphic designer Alberto Seveso shoots high-speed photographs while ink mixes with water. His sinuous ink photographs are vividly mesmerizing and capture the imagination. I hope he prints these on large canvases and will be available for purchase! Below works are from the a Due Colori series: (all images by Alberto Seveso)

item.title: 524 Miles…From El Paso, TX to Tempe, AZ
item.dc:creator: thisamaceinglife
item.description: This is how it works! We always close the show on a Sunday after a few weeks in one city, then raise the curtain the following Wednesday night in the next city. It all happens very fast. To me, it is like magic, because I am never there on Tuesday to see how, in one [...]
item.content:encoded:
This is how it works! We always close the show on a Sunday after a few weeks in one city, then raise the curtain the following Wednesday night in the next city. It all happens very fast. To me, it is like magic, because I am never there on Tuesday to see how, in one day, the crew unloads the 17 Semi’s then reloads our entire show back into a new theater. But, it happens without fail, and by Wednesday morning when I arrive along with Wardrobe, Hair and the Cast, everything looks and works as well as it did in the last city! Magic!

My Husband, Mitch is one of the magicians at the theater on Tuesday morning. Because of that he is never able to ride with us and always flies to the next location. Bri the Super Nanny, Mace, Jetson and I are on our own between cities. We love driving most of the time, but on occasion, we have had to drive many miles in only 2 or 3 days.  2300 miles to be exact from Cincinnati to LA, has been the hardest drive to date, but we did it thanks to a happy baby, caffeine and Tom Petty.

This trip, El Paso to Tempe was a piece of cake, only 424 miles in 2 days. EasyPeasy! So we decided to add 80 miles, a few hours and drive up to White Sands National Park in New Mexico! Joining us in caravan was Janet, a dear friend from the show, her dog, Rocco and cat, Maverick.

Here are a few pictures of our incredible day at Beautiful White Sands

Quite possibly Jetson’s idea of Doggie Bliss! All sand and NO water!

And No leash! (Since it was the off season the ranger allowed us to let the dogs off leash, we were the only people there and we promised to pick up poopies! Read this book to find out why we think SAFE off leash time is important to a dog)

Janet took these amazing pictures of her babies! They are so good she even entered a few in a contest. Vote for them here!I took pictures of my baby (and Super Nanny flipping around in the background)Mace sat for a while, fascinated with the sand flowing through his fingers. I hope in his lifetime he will always take the time to love and appreciate this wonder. Bri and Jetson did a little sand sledding.

Mace got some nuzzles and kisses from his Super NannyA little Mommy Love tooJanet got Kissy with Rocco waiting for sunsetAs we said goodbye to the sun we had to say goodbye to White Sands. Tired and happy we made our way to Tempe. It was such a great day!-Stina, Mace, Bri and Jetson xoxox

item.title: Spring is Here!
item.dc:creator: Jamie Adams
item.description: Like other residents of northern Virginia, I am wondering what happened to the winter, I like the winter but I love the fall. My friends and family consider me strange because I do not like summer. Even though the beaches are filled with beautiful women, I avoid them because I can’t stand the heat. This [...]
item.content:encoded:
Click on photographs to enlarge

Like other residents of northern Virginia, I am wondering what happened to the winter, I like the winter but I love the fall. My friends and family consider me strange because I do not like summer. Even though the beaches are filled with beautiful women, I avoid them because I can’t stand the heat. This is probably because I am a polar bear stuck in a human’s body.

Nonetheless, the seasons come and go as God sees fit. I’ve always thought the personification of nature as a loving, nurturing mother humorous. Unlike my mother, Mother Nature doesn’t realize how much I despise the heat. Oh well, like the other women in my life, there is no way I am telling this one how to do her job.

Spring is here, and I have been taking lots of pictures. Of course, after I post these spring-related pictures I will need to take some pictures of motorcycles in order to get my Man Card back. Spring alters my mood — in a good way.  However, I am sorry to say, Lord Tennyson, that my thoughts don’t turn to love — I am always in love. Let me clarify: In his poem “Locksley Hall,” he wrote, “[I]n the spring a young man’s fancy lightly turns to thoughts of love.“

And then there is Robert Frost’s poem, “A Prayer in Spring”:

Oh, give us pleasure in the flowers to-day;
And give us not to think so far away
As the uncertain harvest; keep us here
All simply in the springing of the year.

Oh, give us pleasure in the orchard white,
Like nothing else by day, like ghosts by night;
And make us happy in the happy bees,
The swarm dilating round the perfect trees.

And make us happy in the darting bird
That suddenly above the bees is heard,
The meteor that thrusts in with needle bill,
And off a blossom in mid air stands still.

For this is love and nothing else is love,
The which it is reserved for God above
To sanctify to what far ends He will,
But which it only needs that we fulfil.

Since I live in northern Virginia, the National Cherry Blossom Festival is a short metro-transit ride away. Since this is the 100th anniversary, I want to provide a brief history and the cultural significance of the cherry blossoms in Japan. I hope that my friend Hiromi and her husband will inform me of any historical or cultural inaccuracies.

In 1912, Mayor Yukio Ozaki of Tokyo gave a gift of 3,000 cherry trees to our nation’s capitol (Washington, D.C.). In March of 1912, First Lady Helen Herron Taft and Viscountess Chinda, wife of the Japanese ambassador, planted the first two trees from Japan on the north bank of the Tidal Basin in West Potomac Park.1

In Western culture, the cherry blossom conjures visions of Japan. In the 2003 movie The Last Samurai, Hollywood harnesses the power of this Western cliché when Samurai Katsumoto says to Tom Cruise’s character, “The perfect blossom is a rare thing. You could spend your life looking for one, and it would not be a wasted life.” Long before Tom Cruise graced us with his presence (insert sarcasm), the Japanese were admiring cherry blossoms. In Buddhist tradition, the breathtaking but brief beauty of the blossoms symbolizes the transient nature of life.2

The practice of hanami (or yozakura) fills parks with thousands of people celebrating under the flowering trees. When I was living in Japan in the early 1990s, I had the privilege of attending the Hirosaki Cherry Blossom Festival. I think Japanese poet Kobayashi Issa captures the communal spirit of hanami in his haiku:

In the city fields
contemplating cherry-trees…
strangers are like friends

Another haiku of his reminds us to live a simple life:

Live in simple faith…
Just as this simple cherry,
Flower, fades and falls.

The blossoms will be in peak bloom this week, and I plan to take Friday off work. In the last two weeks, I have already taken many photographs. Here are some of them:

1. History of the Cherry Blossom Trees and Festival, National Cherry Blossom Festival’s website.
2. Cherry Blossoms in Japanese Art and Culture, an essay by Stephanie Cargile.

item.title: Trekking in Everest Region
item.dc:creator: travellingswallow
item.description: Solu-Khumbu, also known as the Everest Region, is home to the biggest mountains in Nepal and the world. This trek required acclimatization to be taken seriously, thus I had time to write. Again, these are excerpts from my journal as we journeyed through the Himalayas. On the way to Everest Base Camp March 7, 2011.Namche [...]
item.content:encoded:
Solu-Khumbu, also known as the Everest Region, is home to the biggest mountains in Nepal and the world. This trek required acclimatization to be taken seriously, thus I had time to write. Again, these are excerpts from my journal as we journeyed through the Himalayas.

On the way to Everest Base Camp

March 7, 2011.Namche Bazaar. We flew to Lukla in a small plane from Tara Airlines, filled with other trekkers as well. There was a very nice mountain view, but the flight was not as frightening as I expected. There was some turbulence closer to the mountains, which could easily become fatal if the plane is not directed correctly and kept centered. Perhaps the flight back will be more impressive, due to the short, inclined runway used for take-off. This reminds me of what Kenny told me that night back in Sauraha: that he knew I was cool because I said I had to experience flying to one of the world’s most dangerous airports. Anyway, we’ve been taking it slowly, I feel a lot more relaxed than in Annapurna. From Lukla, we backpacked to Jorsalle, where we stayed in a very nice guest house. The rooms were great and we took a stroll by the river, and had a photo session at night with the stars. After we were ready to sleep, the hostel manager told me that they were having a Sherpa dance to celebrate their festival: that day was  the Tibetan New Year. I got everyone out of bed and we watched their singing and dancing. I really enjoyed it, more than the others who were grumpy, having been pulled out of their warm sleeping bags. I really felt a deep love for these men and women showing us their culture.

Next morning- yesterday-  we took it easy to Namche Bazaar, this famous place I had heard of so many times. And we are still here today. One and a half days of acclimatization. This is a village that looks pretty rich, in Kenny’s words, “like a rich, Swiss village.” Our one-hundred rupee rooms have an excellent view of the mountains- priceless- and today we hiked up to a hill with great views as well. The trip has been a laugh, thanks to Xavi, the comedian; I think I can become real good friends with all of them. We’ve even started talking about when and where we will meet again. I don’t want to think of the parting moment; but that is not necessary, we still have a long way to go. Here in our hostel, there are two beautiful little girls. Their Sherpa faces are just fantastic. I don’t get tired of looking at them.

Acclimatizing in Namche Bazaar

March 9, 2011. Tengboche (3867m). We left Namche yesterday morning, after having a relaxed breakfast (of tsampa) and easy-going getting ready. The path was still green, the pine trees presenting us with their magnificent scent. We went up and down, and to the river, and up. It took us much longer than the suggested time to get here. But we made it, despite our breaks. The path really reminded me of Colorado’s Rocky Mountains, except, of course, for the altitude. (…) Here in Tengboche we are close to the altitude of ABC, so our next stop will be higher. We were not planning on staying here today, since we were all feeling pretty well, but Isabel had a rough night, puking. So here we are, and I am glad so, since there is a monastery and I’ve spent the morning there, listening to the monks’ chants, sitting outside, and looking at the mountains and, later, chatting with the monks, by which time Kenny joined me. Unfortunately, it started snowing after lunch, which I would love otherwise, if we were not planning on crossing the Cho-La; we’ll see, I’d like to go to Gokyo, but I also want to remain in the team. I’m sure something will work out. It’s so nice to sit here in the dining room and chill, warm, looking at the snow fall.

Note the Yak Caravan at the bottom

March 11, 2011.Dingboche. It kept snowing for most of the afternoon and towards the evening. Xavi started feeling sick as well, and with Kenny’s bad throat, that left me the only one that wasn’t sick. I went for a walk by myself, after having talked to Isabel for some time. I walked for a while in the snow, went to an abandoned “hut,” walked behind the Trekker’s Lodge’s closed building, and sat in the snow below a stupa memorial, and then under a tree, contemplating the falling snow. I went back to the monastery and waited outside for the chants to end, then said good-bye to the monks. They gave me some fried food to eat.

Next morning, everyone was fine, so we were able to continue. Thus, yesterday we made our way to Pheriche. The environment changed abruptly to a rocky and bushy landscape, the Himalayas getting bigger with every step.  It was cold and windy, and we expect it to remain so for the rest of our journey. We stayed in the first hostel that we found, called Pumori, after the himal (mountain). I took a shower with half a bucket of boiling water and burned my head. On the dining room, I saw some Japanese books and started reading. It really made me want to practice my Japanese. And just like magic, a Japanese trekker showed up and I was able to practice. It made me really cheerful ,and I think Keiko-san too. It was very cold that night, so Isabel and I slept in the same bed, since they were wider than usual. This morning, we talked for like an hour before getting up. (…) It was, finally, painful to get out of bed with the cold, but we took it easy; after breakfast and packing, we headed to Dingboche, thirty minutes away, on the other side of the hill. We’ve spent another acclimatization day here. (…) After lunch, Kenny and I went higher up the hill to see the Ama Dablam glacier better. It was a nice hike and we got to talk one on one. (…) We’ve all been getting closer with each other. Really like a family, a team. The Oh My Buddha Team, as we like to call ourselves.

Photo by IC; Ama Dablam from our window in Dingboche

March 13, 2011. Lobuche.  Yesterday, we hiked farther than planned. We passed Dukla and continued to Lobuche, where we are now. We went up the hill that we had hiked the day before and sort of continued along it on another side. There were many people on the trail, mostly a French group that kept behind us. A dog followed us for a while, and I don’t remember when he left us.  The environment became more and more barren, making the mountains more impressive. That morning, after I woke up fast and went to get water, I met an Argentinian going our way, and found him again in this hostel.  After climbing the hill, there was a memorial for those who have died climbing Everest, especially the Sherpas.  Afterwards, the ground became more snowy and icy. I enjoyed myself thoroughly, despite the cold wind. We didn’t take off our coats the whole way. (…)

Sherpa faces on the way

Lobuche came faster than I expected, so small and desolate-looking in this harsh environment. Last night, after talking with the Argentinian guy again, and playing cards, we decided to go straight to base camp the next morning (today). However, we all had a pretty bad night sleep, and Isabel and I crawled under a blanket to the boys’ room to discuss the situation. Finally, after they crawled to our room, we decided to stay, to Kenny’s great disappointment. I think that today has been the first day of real tension in the group.

I would have made it to base camp, even with my lack of sleep, but I didn’t mind staying here, since I want to be in the mountains as long as possible. After a slow breakfast, we all split, and I sat on the side of a hill for a while. I tried to meditate, but didn’t;  then I tried to control my thoughts as appropriate to the moment, as if that specific moment deserved great, wise thoughts that just weren’t coming to me. Then, I tried to be in the moment, feel the wind, my own presence and essence in the Himalayas, also observing the people moving below. On my way down, I stopped to talk to a Sherpa woman whom I had seen outside her house. My desire to mingle with the local population was soon satisfied and the simple conversation led to me being dressed in Sherpa clothes. It was nice to hang out with her until lunch.

Since lunch, we’ve been sitting in the dining room, and time has gone by pretty fast for me, just chatting and playing cards. I learned to play poker, which has been addictive, perhaps because of my good luck at it. (…) I find it interesting how the image, and even the physical appearance, of a person changes, from the first time you see them, and as you continue to get to know them. I can say this about all the members of my trekking group, especially Isabel, having spent ten days meditating at her side without speaking. Even though I had a good feeling about her from the beginning, it was an enlightening and awakening reminder-after so many conversations with her-to realize how much deeper and complex everyone is on the inside. And this applies to everyone. (…) Which brings me to the thought of treating everyone kindly and, especially, not judging by appearance. Such a basic rule and so easily dismissed. It’s like our brains are just hard-wired for it, like explained in the Dalai Lama’s book. I start noticing more clearly the features of my fellow trekkers, and comparing their current image with that first image of each…how different!

Everest Base Camp (5364m) and Kala Pattar (5643m)

March 16, 2011.Dzonga. On March 14th we reached goal. We woke up early and hiked to Gorak Shep.  The landscape began to get rockier. There was snow on the ground and we crossed frozen rivers. We arrived early and had a substantial breakfast, leaving to base camp around 9:30am (if I remember correctly), after dropping our backpacks. Soon after we left, we were able to see the Khumbu glacier, and farther on, the Khumbu icefall, the glacier ice being much more visible. As we approached, we got closer to the ice, which became bluer and shinier. I had never seen a view like this in my life, and I really enjoyed it. Rocks everywhere, a completely inhospitable, harsh environment. No life at all, just the life of the earth itself, coming straight out from deep inside our planet: mountains which are still growing. Human presence so out of place, so unwelcomed. On a rock, very small, carved-in letters announced that this was base camp, surrounded by prayer flags, or more like wrapped disorderly on it.  Right by it, there is the moraine with the big ice blocks, shining blue in the sun, glowing as if they were melting. Everest was not visible, too far behind.  An amphitheater of pyramid-shaped mountains. Much dryer and harsher than ABC. We took lots of pictures and hugged and congratulated each other several times. It felt good, we were all happy; I could feel the good energy vibrating.

This was also a good night, and we decided not to wake up too early for Kala Pattar. So after breakfast, yesterday, we started going up around 9am. I was feeling good, but my fingers were very cold. We started climbing the hill; the cold wind was absolutely brutal, pushing me everywhere. My fingers were really hurting because of the cold, and I couldn’t help thinking of amputation, thanks to the mountaineering books I have been reading. Also, my stomach felt weird and, just in general, I was not feeling well. Almost on top of the first hill, I got a strong feeling of nausea and decided to go down. Isabel came with me. Going down, just that little bit, was very painful.  I just wanted to get off. However, as soon as I was on that flat, sandy ground again, I found it hard to believe that I was not going to go up. I went inside and sat near the “heater,” warming my fingers.

The British woman I had talked to in the morning was getting ready to go up, and I told her what happened. Very casually, she told me that I should try again. It seemed so natural and logical a decision, that I did it. Isabel decided to stay behind; she said she was at peace with that decision. I was thinking of just going up that first hill. I did not think the view would be so different from the top. The wind no longer bothered me and my hands remained warm. I walked extremely slow, with little steps, and soon got up the hill. The ground flattened for a while, so I kept going. I had to stop often when the wind blew hard, to cover my face and to not use so much energy against it. I enjoyed feeling the force of nature, the wind and the altitude; pulling me down, the gravity. But I kept going, slowly. I don’t know what it was exactly, but how could I leave without reaching that summit? Was it pride? Nature and body against me. It must have been pride, at least in part. How could I not do it, I was there, even if the view would be the same. I found Xavi and Kenny coming down, almost at the top, and they reassured that it was worth it. Fifteen minutes later, I found myself on the top of a small rock serving as summit, surrounded by 360 degrees of cliff and barren mountains. As if I was the center. The wind kept blowing, and for the first time I understood that cliché phrase of feeling oneself so small and insignificant in between those great giants. I not only understood, but I experienced it inside me, like our guru told us in meditation:  to the level of the particle, I experienced insignificance, or perhaps something that cannot be put into words. It was exhilarating, that feeling. I took pictures of the view and myself and went down quickly, after about 20 minutes. The others were waiting for me to move on. I felt re-energized. I was so happy to have done so.

The others were finishing their meals when I got back, so I ordered quickly, and our conversation moved to our experiences, all agreeing that it was the best view we’ve ever seen. (…) I felt responsible that Isabel came down with me on the first try. But she explained that she preferred it that way in the end, since it served as a metaphor for enjoying the journey and not being obsessed with the goal, not always the most important thing.

A pass through the mountains: Cho-La (5368m)

We only made it back to Lobuche that day, since it was so late. There I met a Taiwanese-American named Frank, and invited him to play cards with us. We kept changing our minds about Cho-La, and today we needed to make a decision. (…) We started our day with uncertainty for a plan, however, like magic, it seems like destiny decided for us. We encountered many people just coming down from the Cho-La, and Kenny and I decided to do it. The other two agreed to come to Dzonga, where the path starts, to see something different. The trail, however, was enchanting, I believe, for all of us. Isabel and I felt a great peace all of a sudden. It took us on the side of a hill with massive mountains to our left. Then deeper in, with patches of snow and yellowish ground, a lovely smell Kenny described as cinnamon, a clear sky, and an occasional warm breeze. It turns out that here we are, on the lodge just beneath the pass we will cross tomorrow, together. Finally, after so much discussing it, we are getting it over with. The view of Ama Dablam is fantastic from here. It dominates the sky. Things are uncertain after the pass, we will split up, but I feel calmer about it. Earlier, at the prospect of not doing the pass, I felt uneasy about splitting up for some reason. (…)

Back from the sunset, the snowy slush is frozen, the red-orangey light faded slowly, the clouds lowered entangled in the mountains, like in a love embrace. Ama Dablam looked like a forbidden, prohibited kingdom -a heaven- sacred land in the sky.

March 18, 2011.Drak Nak. I wanted an adventure in the Himalayas, a challenge, physical and mental. The whole trip had been easy so far. (…) With all the acclimatization days, my body felt like new every day of hiking. However, life gave me what I wanted. It came with the Cho-La. We left around 7:10am yesterday, later than all the groups at the hostel. To our surprise, we started, and actually, remained making pretty good time. Hiking through flat ground at first- a similar landscape to the one on the way to the hostel- we soon came across the mountains we needed to cross, looking rather small before us. It took longer than we thought, of course, but it was not that difficult and I enjoyed it quite a lot. We climbed through boulders, hopping from one to the next, putting pressure in our legs and thighs. For me, high steps demanded a lot of energy. My heart pounding fast and hard; I tried to control my breathing to make it deep. Behind us, the mountain scenery rose, white like angels, with Ama Dablam observing everything. Looking back was enough reward for me already.

We got to a point where we needed to go around a mountain, and found ourselves in front of the glacier we needed to cross. A perfectly white landscape. Perched on the mountains, other glaciers glowed blue and shiny in the sun. One of them, to our left, looked like a lizard’s skin of ice that I could peel, it made my teeth shatter. We walked on the glacier, following the exact path on the snow as to not fall on crevasses. I felt joyful. Soon we were close to the pass, and took the “Sherpa way up,” instead of the signaled one. I followed Kenny, who had to turn back to help me cross a particularly slippery part against a rock, putting me out of balance. Underneath it, there was a huge block of perfectly smooth, blue ice.

On top of the pass, around 5330m (Kenny’s altimeter), the view of the other side was just spectacular. It was a gray, black and white landscape of spiky summits on the background, and fallen rocks everywhere- boulders, pebbles. We had lunch with that view- in a way ugly, but at the same time beautiful- it inspired respect for sure. Big, black crows flew nearby and surfed the air lightly, waiting for our food. (…) We made our way down slowly and with difficulty, through loose pebbles, big boulders and slippery snow. It was hard on my knees and kept my attention sharp, aware of my surroundings, controlling every movement with precision, not to fall. After this steep part, we walked on huge boulders for a while, hopping up and down. We saw a few rock markers and kept going with confidence.  Almost at the end, a couple behind us yelled something from the top of the rock fall. I thought they were saying not to go that way, but we yelled back saying that this was the right direction. We got to the river, half frozen, and perhaps around this time the fog started to come in.

Behind, and the way ahead, looked amazingly terrible to me: a dry valley, as if a bomb had wiped all life and only the cold wind dared to stroll, to show its face in this beautifully, unwelcoming place. The river fighting its way through this harshness, perhaps with the hope of bringing life, shedding some light in the darkness. We crossed it, not completely sure that it was the way, and simply continued moving forward, on and on. Sometimes, we seemed to see shining roofs in the distance. The fog was lower, like a ghostly ceiling, the sunlight shining through, and the mountains standing tall, every time more invisible, only their bottom was clear. It was one of the most magnificent sights I’ve seen. My head was pulsing hard with pain and I was getting tired of walking somewhat aimlessly; the back thought of being lost not completely formed in my mind. But this didn’t prevent me from looking back and admiring the scene, and have that feeling of awe rise inside me every single time I looked. Soon we accepted we were lost and tried to find a path. In the distance, we saw a couple of trekkers and yelled to them. They were also lost. Together, we followed some tall stone markers that seemed promising to me, but took us to a yak grazing ground rather than a warm hostel.  By this time, impatience lit a spark in me and I tried to remain objective. It was getting late, we needed to hurry. Again, I stopped and was able to admire the furry yaks, eating peacefully, unaware of our situation, just below the fog.

I wished for a local to come and he did. The French couple had disappeared quickly, having signaled that they had found the place. However, the local Sherpa, the yak herder, pointed to a completely different direction to where the hostel should be an hour away. Confusion flooded all of us, but we followed him. The fog was pretty much settled and we had little other options. Through the way he took us, the snow was high, and soon my feet became soaking wet and cold. (…) In my tired perspective, it seemed like this old man was taking us in circles, turning randomly. I thought he was doing it for the money we hadn’t offered yet, and since we had no other options I would accept the price. We went for a while like this. With some nervousness, I was sure it was all going to turn out fine.

Finally, we started going down a steep slope, covered in snow for the most part. I kept falling on what seemed every other step. I got worried at my lack of energy, but kept moving. At one point, the Sherpa meant to turn back for the second time and we tried to offer more money, but it did not work. He went back to his yaks, and left us at the side of a slippery hill with almost no visibility and the hopes there was shelter below.  We kept moving, resigned, and found out there was a hostel when the guys called out. Reassured, going down became easier, and slowly, the buildings came into view. I was laughing inside at the whole situation, and we walked into the hostel in high spirits. It was great to sit around the hot stove, after getting rid of the wet clothes, and have a nice meal. I had been starving. We discussed our adventure with laughs. I think that in the end we all had a good time. The adventure made my day, and then, I was warm and comfortable. Sleeping in the snow had not been necessary.

Today, the day itself took the decision for us to stay resting here. Fog came around mid-morning, after our sleep-in and slow breakfast. I’ve had a great day, talking around the stove and eating. I’ve felt very calmed and isolated from the world, which feels so far away.

Gokyo Ri (5483m) and back

March 26, 2011.Kathmandu. I am back in Kathmandu, on the rooftop of the Kathmandu Peace Guesthouse. I will try to remember all the details from where I left off.

After our resting day in Drak Nak, the morning of the next day we split. Kenny and I left to Gokyo, and the other two to Namche. The way to Gokyo was pretty cool; we crossed an immense, wide glacier with ice here and there, and a nice mountain view. On the way there, we sat for about 40 minutes,  waiting for a glacier to fall, or rather a piece of ice that was making cracking noises. The ice did not yield to our desire and impatience; it will fall when the time is right. Nevertheless, listening to the cracking noise was an experience in itself. In Kenny’s words “the glacier is alive.” Despite the hostility of the place-lifeless- nature itself is alive, the earth deep inside and in front of us. That is a great example. We kept following the markers and got lost, so we decided to climb a real steep, muddy hill, to make sure that Gokyo wasn’t close.  On top, we couldn’t see it. We checked the map many times and started to go down an old-looking trail on the ridge of a hill, hoping to get there a different way. Luckily, like answering my desperate, but calm, thoughts, I saw a trekker in the distance and called out. We had been very close to it (Gokyo), it was just around the corner. The lake we had been seeing suddenly became three times bigger, and the tiny settlement by it. The Namaste Lodge turned out to be the best place we ever stayed at, with a nice view of the lake from the dining room, double-mattress beds, and extreme hospitality by Pasang, the owner. She gave us free drinks as a welcome and chocolates as a farewell. She had a beautiful, distinct Sherpa face, her cheeks burned red. The clouds came in, so we didn’t go up to Gokyo Ri that afternoon. We met Frank again, and his fellow traveler Walter, from Holland. We all planned to go early next morning, but the fog was still there, thick at 5am. So we stayed another day. We went hiking together to see the other lakes and Cho Oyu Base Camp; but we only made it to the 4rth lake, having sunbathed and chilled several times on the way.(…)

Mt. Everest from Gokyo Ri (the farthest one)

Next day, Kenny and I went up with clear weather and cold air around 5:40am. The moon was full and big in between two peaks, above the lake, and the sun was starting to rise on our right. Going up, I had some kind of mental block, but of course I made it to see the magnificent 360 degree view of a snowy landscape (it snowed the night before). It was impressive like Kala Pattar; however, I liked the sensation of Kala Pattar better, since there, I could just turn around on the spot to see everything; and here, it was a much wider summit and there were many people. Still, it was more than worth it.

After eating, we left for Namche, determined to get there that day. And we did, although at 7pm. I had energy and a light, speedy pace. The trek was one of my favorites. We saw the environment change from hostility to pine forest again, our breathing getting easier as we descended. Still, there were ups and downs, and we had to climb a big mountain before descending even more. Always with Phortse on the distance, and seeming so close, but taking us so long to pass it. How deceiving was the mountain! It is necessary to give up the arrogance of conquering the goal in order for the mountain to yield itself. On the way, the mountain takes it away anyway. It was nice to trek with the sunset. Ama Dablam was magical towards the end.

The last hour was difficult for me, but we made it, to the surprised and hopeless faces of Xavi and Isabel. It was great to be there with their hugs and attention. I took a shower that turned into another ordeal, since the water stopped mid-way. But it was nice to be in the same guesthouse again. Next morning, we headed to Lukla, a 7hr-day, and the hardest for me in the whole trip. My body had no energy and my feet were in pain. On our last hour of trek-the boys gone ahead-a monk gave Isabel and I a thread blessing; for us it symbolized the end of the adventure. In Lukla, we went out to the Wave’s Pub and left our mark as a team.

Thank you Xavi, Isabel and Kenny, for making this journey a memorable one.

item.title: Gymnastics Weekend
item.dc:creator: dorrelledwards
item.description: I recently covered a gymnastic weekend event for Desert Lights in Chandler and it was a blast, I think my favorite event was the floor. I wanted to show you guys a couple of shots of some actions shots that stood out (” even though I shot under very low lighting “). This event was [...]
item.content:encoded:
I recently covered a gymnastic weekend event for Desert Lights in Chandler and it was a blast, I think my favorite event was the floor. I wanted to show you guys a couple of shots of some actions shots that stood out (” even though I shot under very low lighting “). This event was fun once again, it’s amazing how graceful women can be in this sport at the same time, it still can be dangerous in gymnastics. I love it. Leave a comment.

-Rell-
